;每个预测都采用今天的数字，并将其乘以明天的故事。

;

;投资估值、经济前景、政治预测 - 它们都遵循这个公式。我们知道的东西乘以我们喜欢的故事。

;

;预测的诀窍是意识到这就是你正在做的事情。

;

;在富兰克林·罗斯福去世前几周，一位记者问富兰克林·罗斯福是否第二次世界大战即将结束时的雅尔塔会议谈判为欧洲的永久和平奠定了基础。

;

;“如果你能告诉我 2057 年你的后代将是谁，我就能回答这个问题，”罗斯福说道。 。 “我们可以像人类所相信的那样向前看。”

;

;在雅尔塔达成的协议是我们所知道的。他们会坚持多久，他们会被坚持多久，以及还有什么会阻碍他们，这些都只是人们在不同程度上讲述和相信的故事。

;

;任何试图预测人们会做什么的事情。下一个工作也会像这样。

;

;困难的是，虽然我们今天知道的数字可能是真实且经过验证的，但我们乘以它的故事是由你想要相信将会发生的事情驱动的，或者< a href="https://collabfund.com/blog/story/">;什么最有意义;。当;我们今天知道的数字;给人留下这样的印象：你是客观的、以数据为导向的，而;明天的故事;却如此容易受到意见的影响时，预报员就会遇到麻烦。; /p>;

;在评估一家公司时，收入/现金流/利润是我们已知的数字。您附加到该数字的收益倍数只是关于未来增长的故事。

;

;与经济趋势相同。我们有很多数据，但除非你附上一个故事，说明你认为它意味着什么，以及你认为人们接下来会用它做什么，否则这些数据都没有多大意义。

;

;这对我来说似乎是显而易见的。但如果询问预报员，他们是否认为他们所做的大部分工作都是讲故事，你会得到茫然的眼神。充其量。当你基于数据进行预测时，它从来都不像讲故事。

;

;虽然数据驱动的讲故事并不意味着猜测，但它并不意味着预言。

;

;我们可以使用历史数据假设趋势将会持续下去，但这只是我们在一个;事物发生变化的世界中想要相信的故事; 一直如此。

;

;我们可以使用数据来假设疯狂的事件将恢复常态，但这也只是一个不可持续的世界中的故事。 com/blog/ Five-lessons-from-history/">;趋势的持续时间比人们想象的要长;。

;

;很少有事情能逃避现实。 BH Liddell Hart 在;我们为什么不从历史中学习？;一书中写道：

;
;

;如果没有想象力和直觉的帮助，[历史]就无法解释。证据的数量如此之多，以至于选择是不可避免的。有选择就有艺术。那些读历史的人倾向于寻找证明自己正确的东西并证实自己的个人观点。他们捍卫忠诚。他们阅读的目的是肯定或攻击。他们抵制难以忽视的事实，因为每个人都想站在天使一边。

;
;

;在金融领域，这一点是通过这样一句俏皮话来表达的：用 Excel 编写的小说比用 Word 编写的小说还要多。

; ;

; p>;

;这一切都不是坏事。我认为这很现实，这意味着我们所有人都应该牢记一些事情。

;

;;1.事实乘以故事总是等于小于事实。;因此，几乎所有预测实现的可能性都小于 100%。这不是一个大胆的说法，但如果你接受它，它总是会让你有犯错的空间和承受惊喜的能力。

;

;;2.最有说服力的故事是你愿意相信的真实故事，或者是你亲身经历的故事的延伸;，这就是预测如此困难的原因。

;

;;3.如果您想弄清楚某件事接下来会发生什么，您必须了解的不仅仅是其技术可能性;。您必须了解每个人都讲述这些可能性的故事，因为它是预测方程的重要组成部分。

;

;;4.当利率较低时，等式的故事面变得更加强大;。当短期业绩不与利率竞争时，公司的估值大部分来自于它未来可能实现的目标。当然，这只是一个故事。人们可以想出一些疯狂的故事。

;我曾经问过一位成功的作家如何推销一本书。他挥手让我走开，说道：“如果这本书很好，你就不需要推销它。如果这本书很糟糕，再多的营销也无济于事。”

;

;他有点夸张：我认为他的建议有 80% 是正确的。但这;绝对; 80% 是正确的。它几乎适用于任何产品。最好的营销就是好的产品。

;
;

;查理·芒格曾经谈到好市多创始人吉姆·辛内格尔的职业生涯有多么轰动。

;

;播客大卫·森拉问芒格：为什么有这么多辛内加尔很少发表演讲或接受采访吗？

;

;“他忙着工作，”芒格说。

;

;最令人印象深刻的人不会把自己的一生花在社交媒体上或管理他们的宣传。< /p>;

;

;经济学家拉斯·罗伯茨无法弄清楚为什么这么多二战老兵讨厌红十字会。

;

;红十字会？你怎么能恨他们呢？但他一遍又一遍地听到这种声音。

;

;当被问及敌意从何而来时，兽医们一直在谈论甜甜圈。甜甜圈，甜甜圈，甜甜圈。

;

;第二次世界大战期间，红十字会在欧洲各地设立了慰安所，供盟军士兵理发、喝咖啡和吃甜甜圈。对美国人来说是免费的，但英国和加拿大士兵则被收取几美分的费用。这造成了一种等级制度，损害了士气，因此美国将军们最终要求红十字会也开始向美国士兵收费。

;

;突然间，习惯于获得免费甜甜圈的美军也受到了收费。他们讨厌它，认为红十字会是一个利用他们饥饿的贪婪奸商。战后的几十年里，这种怨恨一直存在。

;

;这里有两个教训：一旦你免费赠送了一些东西，就几乎不可能再收取费用，所以要谨慎选择你的商业模式。人们对即使是合理的价格变化也极其敏感，这就是为什么通货膨胀始终是一个情绪问题。

;
;

;Jerry Seinfeld ;最近说过;：

;
;

;观众现在纷纷涌向单口喜剧，因为这是你无法伪造的东西。这就像平台跳水。您可以说您是平台潜水员，但两秒钟后我们就可以知道您是否是。这就是人们喜欢站立的原因。他们可以相信它。其他一切都是假的。

;
;

;他的建议是：“擅长某件事。就是这样。其他一切都是废话。”

;
;

;人口历史学家 TH Hollingsworth 曾经发表过一份对英国贵族预期寿命的分析。它显示出一种奇特的趋势：在 1700 年代之前，社会中最富有的成员的寿命最短，明显低于总人口的寿命。

;

;这怎么可能？

;

;最好的解释是，富人是唯一能买得起所有庸医和假医生的人，他们兜售希望，但却增加了你中毒的几率。

;

;我敢打赌，今天的投资建议也会发生同样的情况。

;
;

;如果对你的小批评明显是错误的，你往往不会在意。如果有什么不同的话，它只会让批评你的人看起来很愚蠢。

;

;如果批评可能是真的，你可能会感到愤怒，因为你知道这是对你身份的真正攻击。

;

;与蒂姆·费里斯 (Tim Ferriss)，海军拉维坎特 (Naval Ravikant) 曾经;说过;：

;
;

;如果我说，“蒂姆·费里斯很胖”，这句话会立即从你身上跳出来。但如果我说，“蒂姆·费里斯和纳瓦尔是假大师”，这可能会打击我们，对吧？掩盖谎言的人在为自己辩护时会变得多么愤怒和正义。

;
;

;1930年11月大选后，共和党和民主党在众议院占据了偶数席位。完美的平局。

;

;当成员宣誓就职时，已有十三人去世，其中大多数是共和党人。取代他们的特别选举对民主党有利，当国会第一次开会时，民主党占据了绝对多数席位。

;

;下次当你听到自信的政治预测时，请记住这一点。没有人知道任何事情，即使它看起来很明显。

;
;

;投资者霍华德·马克斯的一个类似的故事：

;
;

;我讲述了我父亲的赌徒的故事，他有一天，他听说一场只有一匹马的比赛，于是他用租金下了赌注。跑到一半时，马跳过栅栏逃跑了。

;
;
;

;有位教练曾给运动员描述过三分法：训练时，一天的三分之一应该感觉良好，三分之一应该感觉还好，三分之一应该感觉很糟糕。这是一个很好的、平衡的、例行公事的。当你知道自己在逼迫自己，但不要太用力时。冒险，但不要过度。制定具有挑战性的目标，但不要制定不切实际的目标。

;

;我认为你可以将这一点应用到企业、职业和人际关系中：如果事情总是很糟糕，那么你就做错了。如果总是感觉很棒，那么你就很天真、健忘，或者没有发挥自己的潜力。

;
;

;耶鲁大学经济学家罗伯特·希勒 (Robert Shiller) 获得诺贝尔经济学奖，部分原因是他开发了美国全国指数房价可以追溯到 1800 年代。

;

;我曾经问他：他在哪里找到 1800 年代的房价数据？

;

;“图书馆，”他干巴巴地说。

;

;“图书馆。” p>;

;“这是 Grabler、Blank 和 Winnick 所著的一本书，是 20 世纪 50 年代初期国家研究局的一本书。他们有一个很好的分析；很棒的书。我可以推荐你读它，但没有人读它，没有人读它。”

;

;房地产界有一个众所周知的想法，即你可以在没有人愿意拥有的最丑陋的房产上获得最高的投资回报率。生活中的很多事情也是如此：乏味的工作，几乎没有竞争，却能找到一些最伟大的想法。

;
;

;我认识的一位初创公司创始人曾经试图从投资者那里筹集资金。投资人告诉他，“我喜欢你的想法，但我认为这只有20％的机会。”

;

;创始人回答：“百分之二十？哇，你真是个乐观主义者。我认为可能性最大为 10%。”

;

;这句话出自一位创始人之口，他以饱满的热情和精力将一生奉献给了这家公司。

;

;杰夫·贝佐斯曾经;说道;：

;
;

;每个初创公司都不太可能成功。面对现实是有帮助的，但这并不意味着你不能乐观。所以你的头脑中必须有这种二元性。一方面，你知道关于初创公司的基线统计数据，另一方面，你必须忽略所有这些，并 100% 确定它会起作用，而且你同时做这两件事。你脑子里一直存在着这样的矛盾。

;
;
;

;在对阵克利夫兰骑士队之前，马刺队主教练格雷格·波波维奇被媒体问到他的球队如何才能阻止骑士队令人印象深刻的表现。 “你觉得你的防守如何进入传球路线并阻止它？”他们问。

;

;“哦，我们可能不会。如果你愿意的话，我可以给你一些废话。”波波维奇说。

;

;我们需要更多这样的东西。励志啦啦队和谎言之间只有一线之隔。

;
;

;罗纳德·里根曾经讲过这个故事。

;

;有两个兄弟。其中一个是彻头彻尾的悲观主义者。另一个是无可救药的乐观主义者。

;

;父母认为这两个孩子都太不现实了，所以他们和一位精神科医生交谈，精神科医生想出了一个圣诞节的主意：给悲观的男孩一屋子最不可思议的玩具，然后告诉他他们都是为了他。给这个乐观的男孩一屋子的马粪，并告诉他这就是他得到的全部。这应该可以治愈他们。

;

;父母做到了。当他们检查孩子们的情况时，那个带着所有玩具的悲观主义者正在哭泣。 “有人会从我这里夺走所有这些，”他说。

;

;这个满屋子胡言乱语的乐观孩子从未如此快乐过。他正在疯狂地挖掘。 “这里的某个地方一定有一匹小马，”他说。

;

;乐观主义者和悲观主义者对他们看到的信息的反应并不像他们对他们想看到的东西的解释那样多。

;

; p>;

;

;先生。最成功的 YouTube 创作者 Beast 表示，制作一个获得 1000 万次观看的视频比制作 100 个获得 10 万次观看的视频更容易。为什么？因为最好的内容是常青的。十年后它将会像今天一样具有相关性，而且仍然会引起人们的关注，这比试图用一个可能与今天相关但下周二没有人会关心的想法来吸引人们的注意力要强大得多。;

;

;珀西·比希·雪莱 (Percy Bysshe Shelley) 在他 1818 年的诗《奥兹曼迪亚斯》(Ozymandias) 中写道，他在荒无人烟的地方偶然发现了一座被摧毁的千年古迹的废墟。除了底座外，纪念碑上的任何东西都无法识别，上面刻着这样的铭文：

;
;

;“我的名字是奥兹曼迪亚斯，万王之王； /看看我的作品，你们强大，绝望！”

;
;

;100年后没有人会记得你，在做出人生重大决定时记住这一点是有帮助的。

; Tue, 06 Aug 2024 13:47:00 -0400 https://collabfund.com/blog/a-few-little-ideas/ https://collabfund.com/blog/a-few-little-ideas/ 给浴缸注满水

;尽管信息泛滥，但揭露真相似乎比以往任何时候都更加困难。这令人不安，因为当人们找不到真相时，他们不知道该向何处求助。他们不知道该如何回应。他们不知道去哪里寻求指导。结果，他们漫无目的地寻找它。

;

;然而，好消息是，当人们最终找到真相时，他们立即就知道了，因为，正如温斯顿·丘吉尔所说，“真相是无可争议的。”恶意可能会攻击它，无知可能会嘲笑它，但最终，它就在那里。”

;

;最近几周我对此进行了很多思考，在这样做的过程中，我想起了我父亲的一个教训当我们还是孩子的时候，就传授给了我和我的兄弟。我们通常将其称为“装满浴缸”。

;

;我对这一课最生动的记忆是在我们中的一个人丢失了对他来说很重要的东西之后。当他下班回家时，他显然很失望，所以他让我们坐下来说，

;

;;“好吧，孩子们。想象一下你有一个空浴缸和一个装满水的滴管。如果一次加一滴，你认为需要多长时间才能填满浴缸？”;

;

;我们很困惑，而且可能有点害怕，回答道：

;

;;“呃……很久了？”;

;

;我爸爸回答道：

;

;;“没错。很长很长的时间，但如果你有足够的时间，你最终会填满那个浴缸。”;

;

;当他继续说道时，我们两个点头同意，

;

; ;“信任也是如此。每次你们两个做了值得信赖的事情，你们就可以添加一滴。随着时间的推移，这些微小的水滴会积聚起来，直到浴缸充满。而且，当浴缸满了时，你就赢得了我的信任。”;

;

;我记得自己心里想，

;

;“;明白了，爸爸。有道理;。”

;

;但他还没有说完。他的教训还有另外一个方面，

;

;;“但是，孩子们……当你做了一些非常不值得信任的事情时，你就会停止，随着时间的推移，你赚到的所有水都会流入下水道。”;

;

;这个形象一直困扰着我，尤其是在今天，因为似乎很难知道该信任谁或什么。

;

;因此，这提出了两个问题 - 为什么是这种情况吗？我们能对此做些什么？

;

;我发现引用已故查理芒格的几句话很有帮助，他与沃伦巴菲特一起管理伯克希尔哈撒韦公司近六十年，并且，这样做，赢得了无数人的信任。

;

;;;“向我展示激励措施，我将向你展示结果。”;;

;

;虽然技术大大减少了做许多事情（即预订、发送消息、查看天气、获取路线等）所需的时间，但它也;增加了;人们对立竿见影的结果。结果，这极大地改变了推动经济和整个社会的激励机制。

;

;只要看看社交媒体上人们大声喊叫“点赞”、政客迎合他们的基本盘而不是“交叉”就可以了。 “过道”来吸引中间选民，媒体依靠声音和丑闻而不是简单地报道新闻而蓬勃发展，投资者做出极其自信的预测而不是承认不确定的未来。

;

;那么，在哪里这离开了我们吗？

;

;虽然这种行为可以产生他们想要的结果（即通常是金钱和名誉），但它通常需要夸大事实。更令人不安的是，维持这些结果往往需要不断地“提升”自己，这意味着进一步延伸事实。

;

;这样想。

;

;为了增加他们的“喜欢” ，社交媒体上的“影响者”必须描绘出更美好的生活图景（即更多喷绘照片、异国情调的假期、豪车、私人飞机等）。

;

;为了获得更多关注，政客必须将自己的立场进一步推向极端（即，想想谁最常上 MSNBC 和福克斯新闻……不是那些无聊的中间派）。

;

;为了获得更多观众，MSNBC 和福克斯新闻已经做同样的事情。

;

;为了吸引有限合伙人投资一家公司、交易或基金，并在未来获得良好的回报，管理层不仅必须做出大胆的预测，以提高对公司规模的预期。机会是，随着时间的推移，他们必须;超过;这些预测（通常是相当大的数量）。

;

;机会就在这里。

;

What are the odds that during those 50 years I will experience one or more of the following: Wars, recessions, terrorist attacks, pandemics, bad political decisions, family emergencies, unforeseen health crises, career transitions, wayward children, and other mishaps?

;

;One-hundred percent. ;The odds are 100%;.

;

;When you think of it like that, you take debt's narrowing of survivable outcomes seriously.

;

;The other is you think about the kinds of volatile events that could do you in.

;

;Financial volatility is an obvious one – you find yourself unable to make your debt payments. But there's also psychological volatility, where for whatever reason you can't mentally endure your job any longer. There's family volatility, which can be anything from divorce to caring for a relative. There's child volatility, which could fill a book. Health volatility, political volatility, on and on. ;

;I'm not an anti-debt zealot. There's a time and place, and used responsibly it's a wonderful tool.

;

;But once you view debt as narrowing what you can endure in a volatile world, you start to see it as a constraint on the asset that matters most: having options and flexibility.

;Thirty-seven thousand Americans died in car accidents in 1955, six times today's rate adjusted for miles driven.

;

;Ford began offering seat belts in every model that year. It was a $27 upgrade, equivalent to about $190 today. Research showed they reduced traffic fatalities by nearly 70%.

;

;But only 2% of customers opted for the upgrade. Ninety-eight percent of buyers preferred to remain at the mercy of inertia.

;

;Things eventually changed, but it took decades. Seatbelt usage ;was still under 15%; in the early 1980s. It didn't exceed 80% until the early 2000s – almost half a century after Ford offered them in all cars.

;

;It's easy to underestimate how social norms stall change, even when the change is an obvious improvement. One of the strongest forces in the world is the urge to keep doing things as you've always done them, because people don't like to be told they've been doing things wrong. Change eventually comes, but ;agonizingly slower than you might assume;.

;
;

;Dunkirk was a miracle. More than 330,000 Allied soldiers, pinned down by Nazi attacks, were successfully evacuated from the beaches of France back to England, ferried by hundreds of small civilian boats.

;

;London broke out in celebration when the mission was completed. Few were more relieved than Winston Churchill, who feared the imminent destruction of his army.

;

;But Edmund Ironside, commander of British Home Forces, pointed out that if the Allies could quickly ferry a third of a million troops from France to England while avoiding aerial attack, the Germans probably could, too. Churchill had been holding onto hope that Germany couldn't cross the Channel with an invasion force; such a daring mission seemed impossible. But then his own army proved it was quite possible. Dunkirk was both a success and a foreboding.

;

;Your competitors can probably innovate and execute as well as you can. So every time you uncover a new talent you're proud of, temper your thrill with the acceptance that other people who want to win as badly as you probably aren't far behind.

;
;

;Notorious BIG once casually mentioned that he began selling crack in fourth grade. He explained:

;
;

;They [teachers] was always like, “Take the talent that you have and think of something that you can do in the future with it.”

;

;And I was like, “Well, I like to draw.” So what could I do with drawing? What am I gonna be, an art dealer? I'm not gonna be that type. I was thinking maybe I can do big billboards and shit. Like commercial art.

;

;And then after that I got introduced to crack. Haha, now I'm thinking, commercial art?!哈哈。 I'm out here for 20 minutes and I can make some real, real money, man.

;
;

;Incentives drive everything, and most of us underestimate what we'd be willing to do if the incentives were right.

;
;

;When Barack Obama discussed running for president in 2005, his friend George Haywood – an accomplished investor – gave him a warning: the housing market was about to collapse, and would take the economy down with it.

;

;George told Obama how mortgage-backed securities worked, how they were being rated all wrong, how much risk was piling up, and how inevitable its collapse was. And it wasn't just talk: George was short the mortgage market.

;

;Home prices kept rising for two years. By 2007, when cracks began showing, Obama checked in with George. Surely his bet was now paying off?

;

;Obama wrote in his memoir:

;
;

;George told me that he had been forced to abandon his short position after taking heavy losses.

;

;“I just don't have enough cash to stay with the bet,” he said calmly enough, adding, “Apparently I've underestimated how willing people are to maintain a charade.”

;
;

;Irrational trends rarely follow rational timelines. Unsustainable things can last longer than you think.

;
;

;When the Black Death plague entered England in 1348, the Scots up north laughed at their good fortune. With the English crippled by disease, now was a perfect time for Scotland to stage an attack on its neighbor.

;

;The Scots huddled together thousands of troops in preparation for battle. Which, of course, is the worst possible move during a pandemic.

;

;“Before they could move, the savage mortality fell upon them too, scattering some in death and the rest in panic,” historian Barbara Tuchman writes in her book ;A Distant Mirror;.

;

;There's a powerful urge to think risk is something that happens to other people. Other people get unlucky, other people make dumb decisions, other people get swayed by the seduction of greed and fear.但是;你;呢？ ;Me;? No, never us. False confidence makes the eventual reality all the more shocking.

;

;Some are more susceptible to risk than others, but no one is exempt from being humbled.

;
;

;Dr. Dan Goodman once performed surgery on a middle-aged woman whose cataract had left her blind since childhood. The cataract was removed, leaving the woman with near-perfect vision. A miraculous success.

;

;The patient returned for a checkup a few weeks later. The book ;Crashing Through; writes:

;
;

;Her reaction startled Goodman. She had been happy and content as a blind person. Now sighted, she became anxious and depressed. She told him that she had spent her adult life on welfare and had never worked, married, or ventured far from home – a small existence to which she had become comfortably accustomed. Now, however, government officials told her that she no longer qualified for disability, and they expected her to get a job. Society wanted her to function normally. It was, she told Goldman, too much to handle.

;
;

;Every goal you dream about has a downside that's easy to overlook.

;
;

;Historian John Meecham writes:

;
;

;When we condemn [the past] for slavery, or for Native American removal, or for denying women their full role in the life of the nation, we ought to pause and think: What injustices are we perpetuating even now that will one day face the harshest of verdicts by those who come after us?

;
;

;This applies to so many things.

;

;What is the modern version of cigarettes, which were doctor-recommended just a few generations ago? We didn't know dinosaurs existed 200 years ago, which makes you wonder what else is out there that we're oblivious to today. What company is the modern Enron, so obviously a fraud? What do most people – not a few wackos, but most of us – believe that will look something between hilarious and disgraceful 100 years from now?

;

;A lot of history is just gawking at how wrong, how blind, people can be. Disastrously wrong, embarrassingly blind. Millions of people, all at the same time. When you then realize that today will be considered history in a few generations … oh dear.这很不愉快。 But also fascinating.

;
;

;Apollo 11 was the first time in history humans visited another celestial body.

;

;You'd think that would be an overwhelming experience – literally the coolest thing any human had ever done. But as the spacecraft hovered over the moon, Michael Collins turned to Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin and said:

;
;

;It's amazing how quickly you adapt. It doesn't seem weird at all to me to look out there and see the moon going by, you know?

;
;

;Three months later, after Al Bean walked on the moon during Apollo 12, he turned to astronaut Pete Conrad and said “It's kind of like the song: ;Is that all there is?;” Conrad was relieved, because he secretly felt the same, describing his moonwalk as spectacular but not momentous.

;

;Most mental upside comes from the thrill of anticipation – actual experiences tend to fall flat, and your mind quickly moves on to anticipating the next event. That's how dopamine works.

;

;If walking on the moon left astronauts underwhelmed, what does it say about our own earthly goals and expectations?

;
;

;John Nash is one of the smartest mathematicians to ever live, winning the Nobel Prize. He was also schizophrenic, and spent most of his life convinced that aliens were sending him coded messages.

;

;In her book ;A Beautiful Mind;, Silvia Nasar recounts a conversation between Nash and Harvard professor George Mackey:

;
;

;“How could you, a mathematician, a man devoted to reason and logical proof, how could you believe that extraterrestrials are sending you messages? How could you believe that you are being recruited by aliens from outer space to save the world?” Mackey asked.

;

;“Because,” Nash said slowly in his soft, reasonable southern drawl, “the ideas I had about supernatural beings came to me the same way that my mathematical ideas did. So I took them seriously.”

;
;

;This is a good example of a theory I have about very talented people: No one should be shocked when people who think about the world in unique ways you like also think about the world in unique ways you don't like. Unique minds have to be accepted as a full package.

;After tapping in for par on the 18th hole at Augusta National with the sun setting behind its towering pines, Scottie Scheffler claimed his second Masters in three years. Shortly thereafter, the prior year's winner, John Rahm, placed the green jacket on Scheffler's broad shoulders cementing Scheffler at the top of the world rankings.

;

;As I watched the ceremony unfold, it reminded me of something Scott Van Pelt said last spring when he was discussing Scheffler and Rahm's respective paths to the top of the sport. Given they had nearly identical scoring averages (~68.6), I figured their paths were very similar. I could not have been more wrong.

;

;See, Rahm's ascent had come from “risk-seeking”, as evidenced by the fact that he was averaging more than 5.5 birdies per round through the middle of last season and was on pace to become the first PGA player to do so since 2000.

;

;Meanwhile, Scheffler's success had come from “risk-mitigation”, as evidenced by the fact that he had made a bogey (or worse) on fewer than 10% of the holes he had played. Coincidentally, he was also on pace to do something that hadn't been done since 2000.

;

;For all you golfers out there, this should be encouraging because it means success can come in multiple forms, so long as you are disciplined enough to stick to what best suits your game. The trouble is few are willing and/or able to do so. Instead, the vast majority of golfers endlessly pivot.

;

;On one hole they choose to be aggressive and attempt to hit a par-5 in two, only to lay up on the next one. They hit aggressive putts on some holes, then lag putts on others. They play it safe and pitch out from behind trees on the front nine, only to attempt aggressive draws around them on the back.

;

;Why?

;

;Because they let their emotions get the best of them.

;

;This is just the start.

;

;Golfers often change their approaches mid-hole, mid-round, mid-season, and sometimes even mid-swing. It's unquestionably manic. Yet, golfer behavior pales in comparison to investor behavior.

;

;;

;

;Investors are notoriously mercurial. We chase performance, buy high, sell low, and endlessly pursue fads. Bull markets convince us that we are brilliant, when in reality we are often just pawns in another wealth destroying bubble. Bear markets, on the other hand, force us to do things we had previously convinced ourselves we would never do (namely selling at the lows and stop committing to private investments).

;

;This is precisely the reason why nearly every equity fund's ;dollar-weighted returns; are significantly worse than their time-weighted returns and why private equity vintage performance is inversely correlated to the amount of capital that funds have raised (ie, the worst vintages typically come during buoyant fundraising periods). This behavior has been on full display over the past decade-and-a-half.

;

;Like Jordan Spieth's play in the years after he blew a five shot lead in the final round of the 2016 Masters, investors became incredibly risk averse in the wake of the 2007-2009 great financial crisis (“GFC”) after suffering extreme losses. This meant a strong aversion to riskier asset classes like high growth tech stocks and venture capital. However, as is almost always the case, this aversion waned over time as both started to post strong returns and animal spirits slowly returned.

;

;As the GFC fell further into the rearview mirror, investors began shifting into risk-seeking mode and ratcheted up their exposures to these riskier assets, especially with bond yields so low. It started with modest commitments to venture and tech, but quickly ramped up towards the end of the decade.

;

;For a while, things felt good. Check that, things felt ;great; as the highest growth parts of the market posted eye-popping returns. After all, who doesn't love the feeling of hitting shots like ;Phil Mickelson from behind the tree on the 13th at the 2010 Masters; or ;Bubba Watson in a playoff at the 2012 Masters;?

;

;The trouble is, unlike Mickelson and Watson who rarely waver from their risk-on approaches, in 2022 when the NASDAQ fell 40% and venture seized up in the wake of Silicon Valley Bank's failure amid higher rates, investors once again retreated into risk-mitigating mode by failing to add to beaten down tech companies and cutting back on new venture commitments.

;

;When the markets then rallied unexpectedly in 2023 on the heels of the hype around AI and the prospect for lower rates, investors were once again left chasing.

;

;So where does this leave us today?

;

;Investors are once again in risk-seeking mode as evidenced by the fact that individual investors are the most bullish they've been since the fall of 2021, the NASDAQ is once again taking in record flows, and investor confidence is so high that buying protection against a 5% dip in the next year has fallen to what Bank of America strategist Ben Bowler called not too long ago the “cheapest you likely have ever seen”. All at a time when the markets look very expensive.

;

;The question is, why do investors continually behave like this?

;

;Simply because it is in our nature.

;

;As Charlie Munger said,

;

;;“A lot of people with high IQs aren't great investors because they have terrible temperaments. That is why having a certain kind of temperament is more important than brains. You need to keep raw irrational emotion under control. You need patience and discipline and an ability to take losses and adversity without going crazy. You need an ability to not be driven crazy by extreme success.”;

;

;This quote was top of mind when someone recently asked me whether I thought we should materially dial back risk for an institution I serve on the investment committee for. Earlier in my career, I likely would have responded that we absolutely should dial risk back given the current state of valuations, cheap cost to protect via options, extreme confidence, and looser credit conditions. However, the longer I do this, the more I realize the answer is significantly more nuanced.

;

;The fact is I have no idea where markets are headed or whether there is a greater chance markets will crash or compound at reasonable rates of return over the next few years. No one does.

;

;That said, how did I respond?

;

;I simply said that I thought we should stick to our process.

;

;Now, since this particular institution is conservative in nature, has significant outstanding obligations over the next few years, and no meaningful pending inflows of new capital, this meant that yes, we likely should be more defensive and dial back our risk (the same could be said for a 70-year old retiree with no incoming cash flows or someone looking to retire in the next few years).

;

;However, if this institution had a more “risk on” nature, few (if any) future fixed obligations, and a reliable stream of capital inflows, I would likely have said that it did ;not; make as much sense to significantly dial back risk — namely to skip venture capital commitments, rush out of equities into bonds, etc. (the same could be said for a person early or in the prime of their careers with decades left to work and generate income). The reason is simply because doing so would mean straying from its process, timing the market, and maybe most importantly, forcing a future decision on when to switch back into risk-seeking mode…something few can do effectively.

;

;So, what's the bottom line?

;

;Investing is hard, but it doesn't need to be as hard as people make it. As John Rahm and Scottie Scheffler illustrate, success can come in very different forms, so long as you consistently adhere to your process.

;

;Risk-seeking and risk-mitigating can both be successful strategies, so long as you are disciplined enough to stick to them. So today, while the market feels a bit frothy, inflation remains stubbornly high, and the risk to the downside feels greater than the potential to the upside, history has shown that trying to materially adjust your approach to fit the current environment as opposed to your unique circumstances doesn't typically work out well. Only the very elite (or lucky) investors have shown an ability to toggle between risk-seeking and risk-mitigating.

;

;Now before you go thinking you might be elite, remember when I said earlier that both Rahm's 5.5 birdies per round and Scheffler's <10% bogey threshold were coincidentally last accomplished in 2000? Care to guess which golfers accomplished those thresholds close to two-and-a-half decades ago?

;

;Well, what if I told you it wasn't multiple golfers?

;

;What if I told you it was just one?

;

;Tiger Woods.

;

;So, unless you are the investing equivalent of the greatest golfer of all-time, it probably makes sense to stick to one or the other.
